1. use daemon tools or another iso reading software to open the iso 
2. click on the steambackup application 
4. select a folder you wish to install the game to and click ok 
5. wait for it to finish extracting and then open the crack folder in the dragon siege III iso and copy all the files into the folder you created 
6. click on the dragon siege 3 exe and you should be good to go.

for me now everything works under win7 64bit this way:
1.mount the image
2.open it and right click the steambackup.exe and run it as admin
3. choose install folder, C/program files x86 like other games
4. copy the ds3.exe and the steam_api.dll from the crack folder on the image to the installation folder, overwriting existing files
5. if u get problems starting the game, run the ds3.exe in xp service pack 2 compatibility mode
6. rename the game.oeisku file located in the data folder to game.oeisku.org to get german game if u want
to save at beacons press e

To everyone with the hidden folder problem:
Mount image, but do NOT auto run the steam-installer.
Instead, open the iso and run the steam-installer as administrator. The folder will no longer be hidden... Then just crack the game as usual and enjoy the game ;)

Anyone have a quick list of all the keyboard shortcuts?

This sure ain't the same game as the original Dungeon Siege...

Thanks

W, S - forward, back
A, D - rotate camera left, right
ALT - camera control
LEFT CLICK - attack
RIGHT CLICK - move
SPACE - block
SPACE + direction - dodge in direction
SHIFT - strong attack
1, 2, 3, 4 - skills
Q - change stance
E - action
R - quest path
T - items
F - equipment
C - player/journal
M Wheel - zoom
...missing anything? these controls suck, really need remapping.

...edit...
SHIFT + RIGHT CLICK - strong attack
...not just SHIFT.

Here is what I did to get the game works:
1- Run Setup.exe to install Steam (then I have to creat a Steam account then log in and let it running background).
2- Run steambackup.exe to install the game (maybe not need for those who have installed the game already by autorun).
3- Copy all files in folder Cr.a.c.k to the game folder just installed.

Now you go. No more stuck at title screen.

Here is what I did to get the game works:
1- Run Setup.exe to install Steam (just install Steam, that's it. Before I didn't install Steam and the game just got stuck at the title screen).
2- Run steambackup.exe to install the game (maybe not need for those who have installed the game already by autorun).
3- Copy all files in folder Cr.a.c.k to the game folder just installed.

Now you go. No more stuck at title screen.

Okay, I had a problem and this is how I fixed it.

I mounted the rld-ds3.iso and when steambackup started it had a failure. it said it was looking for a file at C:\program files\common files\adobe\adobe drive\cs4\adobedriveCS4_NP.dll 

If you hit okay it just shuts down. If instead you hit cancel it will give you the option to browse for the file. I went to C:\program files\adobe\adobe\adobePatchFiles\ and hit okay and it ran just fine from there.

I first installed the game by creating a folder on my C:/Program files one, named Dungeon Siege 3. Then, when I went to check on it, it wasn't there.

I tought I did something wrong, so I re installed it, again on C:/Program Files but this time I let the game create its own folder named Dungeon Siege III. Went to check, nothing.

At that time I realized I had something like 5 GB's of space being used by two installed DS3 folders I could not see. 

I ran the installer once again and, to my surprise, only when doing THAT I could see the damn folders, but I couldn't delete them nor manipulate them in any way.

Strange thing is, when I ran the installer in admin mode, I couldn't see the folders, not even from the installer itself. Ran it again on normal mode and then they appeared again.

So, short story: the damn folders exist, they're using my space, but the only way I have to see them is from a installer that does not allow me to manipulate them.

If anyone has any idea on how to delete these damn things I would really appreciate it.
Also, controls suck and there is no camera control whatsoever. I feel like playing Castlevania on N64.

GERMAN, ITALIAN, ESPANOL or FRENCH????
example: english to german
open game folder and change:
data_localized_de.oaf > data_localized_en.oaf
and
data_localized_vo_de.oaf > data_localized_vo_en.oaf
and rename the both original en.oaf > de.oaf

now u can play the game in the language u want!

okay, here is how you fix the "invisible" dungeon siege 3 folder:

right click steambackup and run as administrator. you have to do this otherwise the install wont finish and you get this ghost folder that you cant do shit about.

i still dont know how to get rid of the ghost folder, what i did was just install in my programs folder the first time. i couldnt see the folder, but win7 could when i did a search on it. so next time i ran as admin and installed in the same folder i did the first time (programs folder) and hopefully the old ghost folder got overwritten.

I have played both. You still have freedom of a sorts with this game, it's just lacks the sense of freedom to it.
As for the "Bound" characters, eh, it's a pain in the ass, but A LOT of games have bound characters where you can't change their appearance. Not surprising.

While alot of it is more or less them going backwards, the game itself is still good. then again I'm not a teenager who lives on shooting people in high graphics. I'm the type who enjoys a good plot and a decent game despite it's flaws.

To make offline coop work with 2 controllers
Do the following:
DL: XBOX 360 emu http://www.tocaedit.com/IB/index.php?automodule=downloads&showfile=4

You must have 2 controllers with joystick analogs, PS2, XBOX360, Logitech 

Unzip the file to your DS3 Folder, then open the file xbox360cemu

Copy and paste PAD1 details (Key bindings) onto PAD2, below the "INDEX=" line,  

Set PAD2 INDEX= 1 

Test Controller 2 by using the application XinputTest that comes with the file

Make sure the start button is activated on the 2nd Pad

Start the game and enable Gamepad support on the options menu

Go through the character select screen, and let player 1 skip all the cutscenes to in-game

Get player 2 to press start, select a character on the pop up menu, you cannot select the same character P1 is using.

And you get the second player in the game without using another computer.

Specified Keybindings between your controller and the XBOX 360 emu is a bit technical.

Thanks to RELOADED and the makers of the XBOX 360 controller emu project

For people, who don't have XBOX360 wireless controllers or supported PC controllers like me

look for the XBOX 360 controller emulation program.  Unzip it to where the .exe file is in your pc hard drive and then it'll work on ANY controller with an Analog Stick e.g. PS2/1 Layout.  I tested this with a USB generic PS2 pad and it WORKS!

To enable gamepads in DS3, go to options, then gameplay and highlight gamepad support

Many people mentioned the game starting properly, but not being able to see the menus and so.

This means you are missing a component on your computer. In the installation folder you will find a folder called redist. Inside you will find a exe file called "vcredist_x86" and a folder called DirectX. Use the "vcredist_x86" file, and then use DXSETUP inside the DirectX folder.

Atleast this solved the issue for me. I am not sure which program I was missing, and therefore installed both and included them in this post.

For those of you having the problem not seeing the game folder after installation.

Extract all files from the ISO into a folder on desktop.
Then run the steambackup file as admin.
It should let you install now, also letting you access the game directory.

I think this is only Windows 7 related.

in my opinion they have DESTROYED the whole franchise with this game

So far, so good. No hitches downloading or installing. The game's not a hardware hog, my PC can run it on high settings without any lag, I'm satisfied on that point. Art style is also reasonably satisfactory.
This is no triple A title as is evident in dialogs, overall story and lack of cinematic cutscenes. But hey, I'm enjoying it better than first Dungeon Siege, and I played it back in its day.
I don't know how this has changed compared to Dungeon Siege, which I didn't play, but compared to the first, I'm pleased with the changes.

Both combat and dialog are fluid, even if the latter needs the camera switching to face our character when he or she speaks, if not also better scripting, but then, I haven't played halfway yet.
Voice acting could be better. The ones for the available characters being most pertinent, I only minimally respect 2 of the works, the voicing of the knight (which does a good job of diluting his all-too-asian look) and of the gipsy gunslinger, which sounds rather attractively exotic, in that original gipsy russian accent. If that matters to you at least as much, leave the other 2 aside for starters, their voicing is insipid and weak.

But back to the bottom line, while this is no blockbuster, it certainly can be fun, albeit boring if you're one to delve into the lore as much as is allowed us (reading scrolls and book passages is tedious, somehow, wonder if that was just chance). Again, though, much better experience than what I remember from the first, which was one of the Diablo clones so trendy at that time, being a hack & slash dungeon crawl with an all-too large party of companions who were barely interactive and whom you had to micromanage to make proper use of.
Hm... it's been a while. I don't know for sure. Just know I didn't enjoy it well and quit, which I rarely do. This one's going a different way.
